headline: Early Start with John Berman and Zoraida Sambolin
subHeadline: Southern Airlines Cancels Thousands More Holiday Flights; Buffalo Blizzard Death Toll Now 27; Transcript: Trump Press Secretary Learned of January 6 Attack at Lunch; Biggest U.S. Business Stories of the Year. Aired 5-5:30a ET

utterances.speaker: WHITNEY WILD, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Welcome to our viewers in the United States and all around the world. I'm Whitney Wild.More airport chaos today for people trying to get home after Christmas. Thousands more flights have been canceled as airlines struggle to recover from the massive holiday winter storm. No airline hit harder than Southwest. Of about 2,800 U.S. flights already canceled today, 2,500, about 90 percent are southwest. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Challenge for our flight crews being stuck in locations, not where they need to be along with the aircraft. You know, at this point, we're working to accommodate our customers as best we can and offer the most options that we can to get folks back home or to their vacation spots or holiday celebration spot at this point.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: CNN's Lucy Kafanov is in Denver, one of the worst hit hubs in the country.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I wasn't anticipating a nightmare but it became a nightmare, it did.LUCY KAFANOV, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice over):  Christmas may over but for thousands of passengers, the travel nightmare goes on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They canceled our flight and they said they can't help us. So, we don't know what to do.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: Southwest Airlines at the top of the list for cancelations. The airlines ticketing counter at Baltimore's BWI Airport a zoo, Denver Airport's lines for the Southwest ticket counter even longer.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA SOKOLOWSKI, SOUTHWEST PASSENGER
utterances.sentences: And we have to wait in a line that was four hours and we're still in line and nobody is giving us any direction on what line to get in. It's a total you know what show here.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: And for those trying to call to rebook, well, good luck getting through.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Calling Southwest, calling the airlines, they're nowhere to be found. I actually got hung up on multiple times.

utterances.speaker: DAVID CANUT, SOUTHWEST PASSENGER
utterances.sentences: The problem is that Southwest, they don't give any answer, they don't answer the phone.

utterances.speaker: JASON FRIEDE, SOUTHWEST PASSENGER
utterances.sentences: There's no option to rebook anything online. Oh, I've also been on hold for 5 hours and 43 minutes.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: Passenger Jason Friede, shows us the proof.In a statement to CNN, Southwest Airlines said it is experiencing disruptions across our network as a result of the winter storm's lingering effects on the totality of our operation. In the wake of dangerously cold temperatures and winter weather across the nation, airlines canceling thousands of flights on Monday -- MICHAEL JUSTICE, FAMILY'S FLIGHT WAS CANCELED:  They were scheduled to fly out on Saturday and canceled flight after canceled flight until this morning now it's stand by hoping they'll get on to get home.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: -- thousands more flights delayed.

utterances.speaker: MANOMAY MALATHIP, FLIGHT CANCELED
utterances.sentences: Just delay, delay, delay, rinse and repeat.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: At airports across the nation, long lines, chaos, frustrated passengers and luggage piling up.

utterances.speaker: AZIZA MUSTEFA, FLIGHT CANCELED
utterances.sentences: There is a lack of communication. There is no transparency. There's no honesty.I don't know what is going on. There's no staff. It's okay if there is no staff but we just want them to be honest with us and I could just go home. But we can't go home because we don't know where luggage is. Is it here in Atlanta, is it in Chicago? We have no idea.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: Some passengers choosing to look at the bright side.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA GRAY, FLIGHT CANCELED
utterances.sentences: It was like super stressful. But, I mean, just happy I got to see my family for Christmas, and, hey, I'm off this week, so I'll be good.

utterances.speaker: KAFANOV
utterances.sentences: Others finding creative solutions for their journeys home.

utterances.speaker: JOHN MCCONVILLE, FLIGHT CANCELED
utterances.sentences: Instead of waiting on a maybe flight and paying through my proverbial nose for a rental car, if I'm able to get one, I called a friend of mine. I'm driving a rental cargo van down to Nashville, Tennessee.(END VIDEOTAPE) KAFANOV (on camera):  Southwest Airlines issuing a statement on Monday saying, quote, with consecutive days of extreme winter weather across our network behind us, continuing challenges are impacting our customers and employees in a significant way that is unacceptable. The airline adding, quote, we recognize falling short and sincerely apologize but that is cold comfort for the hundreds stranded here in Denver and across the nation. Lucy Kafanov, CNN, Denver.

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: Nothing like ending your holiday like that.President Biden has now approved an emergency declaration for western New York and what was seen there was the worst blizzard in a generation. There were 49 deaths across the country as a result of this coast-to-coast storm and 27 of them were in Erie County, New York. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) MARK POLONCARZ, COUNTY EXECUTIVE, ERIE CO., NEW YORK:  I am aware of additional bodies that have been recovered and are being brought to our temporary morgue. We've had so many bodies and various hospitals are full, and we're just having to go through and determine that if the individuals had died from a blizzard-related death, we unfortunately expect that many of them will. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Parts of Buffalo pummeled with up to 43 inches of snow and hurricane-force winds. And the death toll of at least two dozen people in the area.

utterances.speaker: SHERIFF JOHN GARCIA, ERIE COUNTY, NY
utterances.sentences: There's going to be a lot of welfare checks. And unfortunately, I have a bad feeling about that. I think that that toll is going to go up. It's just gut-wrenching.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Erie County, New York, brought to a literal standstill with people trapped in their homes and cars. POLONCARZcould not respond to emergency calls because of how severe the conditions were.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: County officials sending in specialized trucks to rescue the rescuers.

utterances.speaker: GARCIA
utterances.sentences: I couldn't see two feet in front of my vehicle. And we had to rescue deputies. We had -- so, we brought in snow mobiles, UTVs, ATVs.When fire rigs are getting stuck, the heavy equipment, you can imagine what happens to the public.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: While most major highways have at least one lane clear for emergency traffic, many residential roads are still impassable with vehicles abandoned in the middle of the street.

utterances.speaker: HOCHUL
utterances.sentences: We have had snowplows, major snowplows and rescue vehicles. I saw them myself in ditches buried in snow.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Officials urging residents, stay home.

utterances.speaker: HOCHUL
utterances.sentences: Stay off the roads so we can continue to rescue people, get them safe, and make sure that the roads are clear so that we can reopen our community as soon as humanly possible.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Buffalo under a driving ban, but that hasn't stopped some from taking advantage of the situation. Police have made arrests for looting. Videos on social media shows looters at work, merchandise being carried out on foot.

utterances.speaker: MAYOR BYRON BROWN, BUFFALO, NY
utterances.sentences: People who are out looting when people are losing their lives in this harsh winter storm is just absolutely reprehensible.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: All while thousands of homes and businesses are still without power. One family who lost their heat tried to make it to a hotel on Christmas.

utterances.speaker: DANIELLE TISDALE, SPENT CHRISTMAS AT BUFFALO FIREHOUSE
utterances.sentences: You couldn't see anything. You couldn't see a stoplight. You kind of just had to drive through the intersection praying basically.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Their prayers answered by airport firefighters who were able to rescue the Tisdales along with dozens of other trapped drivers.

utterances.speaker: DEMETRICE TISDALE, SPENT CHRISTMAS AT BUFFALO FIREHOUSE
utterances.sentences: Those guys were amazing at the fire house. They treated us with nothing but love and they welcomed us with open arms.

utterances.speaker: MARQUEZ
utterances.sentences: Miguel Marquez, CNN, Western New York.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: Travel remains treacherous on the roads in the northeast and upper Midwest. But the conditions are expected to get a little bit better over the next few days.CNN meteorologist Chad Myers is live in the weather center. So, Chad, it's going to warm up. But here's what I worry about -- I worry about a warm-up during the day and dropping below freezing overnight, which is so dangerous. The ice with a little bit of water on top, that is just -- you can't even stand on that.

utterances.speaker: CHAD MYERS, AMS METEOROLOGIST
utterances.sentences: You stole my lead, Whitney. That was exactly where I was going with this.

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: I'm from Michigan. I've lived there. I've seen this movie too many times.

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: All right. The hits keep coming. Chad Myers, thank you.

utterances.speaker: MYERS
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: All right. Turning now to the border. The number of people seeking asylum by one estimate has never been higher. Researchers at Syracuse University find that there are nearly 1.6 million asylum applications pending in U.S. immigration courts.CNN has learned there are about 22,000 migrants in northern Mexico hoping to be let into the U.S. Officials think that number is going to get bigger if the Supreme Court lifts the temporary hold and title 42. That is the Trump area immigration policy used to keep migrants out as a pandemic control measure. The Biden administration has asked the court to keep Title 42 in place until at least today. New York Congressman-elect George Santos has admitted he stretched the truth on his resume. The Republican is it apologizing for the first time since "The New York Times" raised questions about his background. In a pair of interviews, Santos admits he never graduated from college and be never worked at Goldman Sachs or Citibank. (BEGIN AUDIO CLIP) CONGRESSMAN-ELECT GEORGE SANTOS:  I'm not a fraud. I'm not a criminal who defrauded the entire country and made up this fictional character and ran for Congress. I've been around a long time. I mean, a lot of people know me. They know who I am. They've done businesses for me. I'm not going to make excuses for this but a lot of people overstate their resumes or twist a little bit. I'm not saying I'm not guilty of that. (END AUDIO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: Santos also says that he's going to go ahead and take the House seat. CNN has reached out to the House GOP leadership as well as the national Republican congressional committee. So, more on that. Stay tuned.Still ahead on EARLY START: New revelations about the press release the White House drafted but did not sent out in the wake of the 2020 election. Plus, Vladimir Putin says he's ready to talk about peace but will Ukraine listen? And the changing face of restaurants. Are people ever going to get their appetite back for eating out after the pandemic? More on that next. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [05:15:24]

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to EARLY START.New details are coming to light in how and when Trump aides first learned of the January 6 attack on the Capitol. In a batch of transcripts newly released by the January 6 Committee, then Press Secretary Kaylee McEnany says she learned the extent of the siege while she was grabbing some lunch. CNN's Sara Murray brings us details from these highly anticipated interviews. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: KAYLEIGH MCENANY, TRUMP WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: Of the entire White House --SARA MURRAY, CNN POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  Donald Trump's former White House press secretary -

utterances.speaker: MCENANY
utterances.sentences: The violence we saw yesterday at our nation's capitol was appalling.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Didn't realize the full extent of the violence at the Capitol until she settled in to eat a turkey sandwich for lunch on January 6th. Kayleigh McEnany telling the January 6th committeeMcEnany saying she was piecing together what was playing out at the Capitol, not merely sitting by as the attack unfolded. I in no way, shape or form would eat a turkey sandwich if I thought the Capitol Hill was being sieged. How White House officials learned of rioters storming the Capitol on January 6 just one of the details emerging as the House Select Committee releases new batches of transcripts from roughly a thousand witness interviews. REP. BENNIE THOMPSON (D-MS):  The Select Committee intends to make public the bulk of its non-sensitive records before the end of the year.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: A separate transcript revealing how the White House crafted a press release in December 2020 calling for the firing of anyone who accepted the election results. Hours earlier, then-Attorney General Bill Barr had told the "Associated Press" there was no widespread voter fraud.According to the draft press release: Anybody that thinks there wasn't massive fraud in 2020 election should be fired. The press release was never sent and Barr resigned from the White House later that month. Since then, he hasn't held back in criticizing Trump's election lies. WILLIAM BARR, FORMER ATTORNEY GENERAL:  I was somewhat demoralized because I thought, boy, if he really believes this stuff he has, you know, lost contact with -- with -- he's become detached from reality. And I went into this and would, you know, tell him how crazy some of these allegations were. There was never -- there was never an indication of interest in what the actual facts were.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The trickle of transcript revelations coming after the committee recommended that the Justice Department bring criminal charges against former President Trump.REP. JAMIE RASKIN (D-MD):  There was a conspiracy to defraud the United States, to exchange an honest to goodness presidential election for a counterfeit election.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Trump's legal team downplaying the committee's findings.

utterances.speaker: TIM PARLATORE, TRUMP LAWYER
utterances.sentences: The report itself is not of much value. You know, it's written by politicians for political purpose.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And dismissing its criminal referrals, even as Trump faces scrutiny from a DOJ special counsel that is now investigating his attempts to overturn the 2020 election.

utterances.speaker: PARLATORE
utterances.sentences: The referral itself is pretty much worthless. The Department of Justice doesn't have to follow it.(END VIDEOTAPE) MURRAY (on camera):  Now, when it comes to the committee, they've released criminal referrals and their final report. But so far, they have only scratched the surface when it comes to releasing all that underlying evidence. They released fewer than 100 transcripts, and interviewed roughly 1,000 witnesses. So, we have many more days of transcript revelations ahead of us. Sara Murray, CNN, Washington.

utterances.speaker: WILD
utterances.sentences: Sara Murray, thank you.All right. Some quick headline from across the country now. Fire officials in Cumberland County, Tennessee, believe for adults and two children died after a house fire Monday. Sheriff's office is investigating. They don't think any foul by happened here. Jackson, Mississippi, is struggling to get water pressure back after cold weather triggered breaks and water lines. The citywide boil water notice remains in place there. Arizona's Democratic Governor-elect Katie Hobbs and Maricopa County are asking a court to impose financial penalties on Republican Kari Lake after a judge ruled against Lake's efforts to overturn the election. Hobbs and the county want $25,000 basically as punishment. Hobbs is also seeking more than $600,000 in attorney fees. Now, CNN's Christine Romans with the biggest business stories of 2022. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Crypto crash and streaming slowed, the recession debate raged, Elon Musk chaotic Twitter takeover and the energy market turmoil raise the prices at the pump.These are the top business stories of 2022. Number 10: Crypto crashed amid the downfall of its biggest exchange. Even flashy Super Bowl ads --

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Couldn't hold off the shill of a crypto winter as investors ditched risky assets.

utterances.speaker: PAMELA BROWN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Has the bitcoin bubble finally burst? Part of a crash that is cost investors more than a trillion dollars.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: A downturn made worse by the implosion of the world's largest crypto exchange, FTX, over claims that it missed used customer money.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The $32 billion company that plunged into bankruptcy basically overnight.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Leaving millions of customers scrambling to recover funds. A class action suit for celebs who endorsed FTX --

utterances.speaker: TOM BRADY, NFL PLAYER
utterances.sentences: I'm getting into crypto.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: And attracting government scrutiny.

utterances.speaker: VICTOR BLACKWELL, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: FTX is prompting investigation by federal prosecutors now.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Disgraced FTX founder, Samuel Bankman-Fried or SBF saw his multi billion dollar fortune evaporate.SAMUEL BANKMAN-FRIED, FTX FOUNDER:  I think that there may be $100,000 or something like that.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Before being arrested on fraud and conspiracy charges, SBF's legal team says it's considering all options.Number nine: America faces a housing crisis.

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Americans are struggling to keep up with rising home prices.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: The pandemic altered the housing market, delayed construction, kept supply low, while demand spike, creating a crisis of affordability.

utterances.speaker: KATE BOLDUAN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Housing prices hit a record high in April.

utterances.speaker: MATT EGAN, CNN REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Prices are going up.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve's inflation fight more than doubled mortgage rates.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Mortgage rates, now topping 7 percent, a 20 year high.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Pricing out many Americans.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: How many properties do you think you've explored?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thousands, thousands.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Home sales dropped, while rental cars hit rented highs.Number eight, Wall Street soured on streaming amid a slowdown. 2022 ushered in a new era for streaming services.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Netflix lost 200,000 global subscribers. The last time Netflix lost subscribers was October 2011.

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Growing losses at Disney Plus.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Streaming stocks tanked as the days of meteoric growth seem to be over.So, Netflix introduced ads, a move it had resisted and will crackdown on password sharing. While Disney saw a leadership shakeup.

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Disney has ousted chief executive Bob Chapek after only two years on the, job replaced him with a familiar name. His predecessor, Bob Iger.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: But all of the major players revised plans, cutting cost to creating profitable business models instead of relying on subscriber growth.Number seven, a nationwide rail strike looms and is averted, not once but twice. The first came in September.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Some 60,000 engineers are trying to walk off the job as soon as Friday.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It wouldn't be the first nationwide rail strike in 30 years.

utterances.speaker: ANA CABRERA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Nearly one third of the nation's freight could come to a standstill.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Rail workers, working nonstop through the pandemic demanded better conditions as freight companies rigged in record profits. Negotiations dragged on threatening a fragile supply chain so the White House stepped in with the labor secretary, brokering at 11th hour deal.

utterances.speaker: ERIN BURNETT, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Labor unions and rail lines reaching a tentative last minute deal.VANESSA YURKEVICH, CNN BUSINESS & POLITICS CORRESPONDENT:  But, now the steel does go to the union members.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: But rank and file workers want a paid sick, time not included in the agreement.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Workers at the biggest and most powerful royal union have voted down a kind of contract deal.

utterances.speaker: YURKEVICH
utterances.sentences: And now you have four real unions who have voted it down altogether.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: This time, Congress stepped in, passing a bill, forcing workers to accept the deal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The joint resolution has passed.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: And stay on the job.Number six, Americans returned to the skies in record number but airlines couldn't handle the influx.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Huge lines are greeting travelers at airports across the United States.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Experts are warning that it's going to be a summer of travel health.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Some days saw thousands of flights delayed.

utterances.speaker: CABRERA
utterances.sentences: More than 2,100 are delayed.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Or canceled, especially over holiday weekend.

utterances.speaker: PETE MUNTEAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Forty-five thousand flight cancellations nationwide since the first of June.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: One major reason, not enough crew members. Airlines trim staff during the pandemic, so any disruption like bad weather sparked chaos.Number five, a rough year for Wall Street amid a tech wreck. The breathless post-COVID rally ended this year.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: The S&P 500 has fallen into what investors call a bear market.

utterances.speaker: RAHEL SOLOMON, CNN BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: This was the worst day for the Dow since June, up 2020.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Investors reacted to rising prices and the Feds aggressive campaign to fight them. Raising the specter of a recession, while also hurting high growth stocks like tech.

utterances.speaker: RICHARD QUEST, CNN BUSINESS HOST
utterances.sentences: Tech stocks have plunged since the start of this year.

utterances.speaker: WOLF BLITZER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Alarm bells are ringing for the U.S. economy tonight.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The U.S. economy shrank for the second quarter in the row. That is the common definition of a recession.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: While big business voices offered dire warnings.

utterances.speaker: JEFF BEZOS, AMAZON FOUNDER
utterances.sentences: If we're not in a recession right now, we are likely to be in one very soon.DOUG MCMILLION, WALMART PRES. & CEO:  Customers are more budget conscious that have been under inflation pressure now for months.

utterances.speaker: JAMIE DIMON, JPMORGAN CEO
utterances.sentences: I think policy makers should be prepared for the worst.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: But, despite the gloom of hot inflation and higher rates, the U.S. economy was resilient. With the labor market so strong, companies were fighting for workers.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: There are 1.9 open jobs for every unemployed person.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: And, people kept shopping, driving growth.

utterances.speaker: ALISON KOSIK, CNN BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Recession fears don't deter U.S. shoppers in a record setting Black Friday.

utterances.speaker: CABRERA
utterances.sentences: American shoppers shelled out an all-time high, $11.3 billion.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Wrapping up 2022 with the recession of questions still unanswered.Number three, Elon Musk chaotic Twitter takeover. The billionaire began building his stake in January, becoming the largest twitter shareholder before offering to buy the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: QUEST
utterances.sentences: Elon Musk makes a $41 billion hostile bid for Twitter. ROMANSagreed to sell itself before Musk did an about-face in May.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Musk is trying to back out of buying the social media giant, saying that Twitter's withholding vital information.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Then came months of legal maneuvering, complicated by revelations from a whistleblower.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The company cybersecurity failures make it vulnerable to exploitation.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Still, Musk eventually completed the deal instead of heading to trial. He immediately slashed jobs.

utterances.speaker: JOHN KING, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Only have the company's employees, now, out of jobs.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: While rolling out other changes, including trying to launch paid verification and reinstating controversial figures including former President Trump.Number two, energy market turmoil raised prices at the pump. Russia's war on Ukraine threatened oil supplies, sending global prices soaring.

utterances.speaker: JULIA CHATTERLEY, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: That's a seven-year hike. U.S. crude, in the meantime, multi year hike too.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: That affected gas prices.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Gas prices here in the United States, reached record highs.

utterances.speaker: CABRERA
utterances.sentences: And that's up by a staggering 60 cents in just one week.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Many Americans couldn't afford to fill up the tank. So, President Biden released oil from the strategic reserve and blasted U.S. oil companies.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Their profits are a windfall of war.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: While also asking them to pump more oil.He did the same with Saudi Arabia during the controversial visit in July. But OPEC plus did the opposite, slashing production in October. And, an attempt to boost oil prices finally weighed down by concerns over a global slowdown. Gas prices also fell and, in the, year cheaper than before Russia invaded Ukraine. Number one, the Fed's aggressive fights to team decade height inflation. Americans paid high prices again this year.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Inflation in the United States, soaring to a new 40-year high.

utterances.speaker: CABRERA
utterances.sentences: Across the board, you're paying way more for just about everything.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, the Central Bank jacked up interest rates, seven times to help even rolling out bumper three quarter point hikes four times in a row. And the Fed isn't finished.

utterances.speaker: JEROME POWELL, FEDERAL RESERVE CHAIR
utterances.sentences: We continue to anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Some worried the Fed's higher rates will spark a recession. They're already shaking markets and raising credit mortgage payments. But, have they lowered consumer prices? There is no clear signal yet. One thing is for sure, the effects will continue to work their way through the economy into next year.(END VIDEOTAPE)
